title: Poughkeepsie couple wins $10million on scratch-off lottery
title_page: Poughkeepsie couple wins $10million on scratch-off lottery | Daily Mail Online
text:
A Poughkeepsie couple is cashing in big bucks after they hit a $10million jackpot on a New York lottery scratch-off ticket.
James Silverence, 50, bought the last six tickets for the lottery's 50th anniversary game at Stewart's Shop in Red Oaks Mill to split with his wife Sylvia Silverence, 53.
Mr Silverence, who works in the elevator industry, had gone into the store to claim $125 from previous winnings, when he heard a customer complain about losing and it sparked his confidence.
Multi-millionaires: Sylvia and James Silverence won $10million after scratching off a jackpot in the New York Lottery
Winner: James had purchased the winning ticket at Stewart's on Vassar Rd in Poughkeepsie
'The lady ahead of me had purchased four of the $10,000,000 cash tickets and didnâ€™t win. There were six tickets left so I put in some extra money and got them all,' he told the Hudson Valley Post on Thursday.
The father-of-four spent $180 on the tickets and went home to split them with his legal assistant wife.
Mrs Silverance scratched her first ticket and was stunned to see she had just become a multi-millionaire after finding the word 'jackpot' under the matching number 23.
The mother covered the word with her finger and walked over to her husband in disbelief. When she revealed the prize, the couple started screaming.
She said the two were so shocked they had to check their 'blood pressure.'
The new millionaires claimed their prize on January 23 but were presented with a giant check by lottery representative Yolanda Vega on Thursday afternoon.
The Silverences' winnings are the biggest prize the lottery has offered through a scratch off.
Finally rich: The couple had regularly purchased tickets, but were still stunned to see they had won such a large prize. They'll each receive $3.3m in one lump sum after taxes
The good life: The family may be multi-millionaires, but they said they plan to stay in their Poughkeepsie home
The couple agreed to split the cash evenly and will be receiving $3,309,000 each after taxes in one lump sum.
As far as spending their cash, James and Sylvia said they do not want the money to change their lives drastically and are planning to put some of it towards their four sons' college education.
As for the future, Mr Silverence said he would keep his job and the family plans to stay in their upstate New York home.
